q: What is the purpose of statins?
i: Having a high level of LDL cholesterol is potentially dangerous, as it can lead to a hardening and narrowing of the arteries (atherosclerosis) and cardiovascular disease (CVD).
a: Statins are offered to lower LDL cholesterol levels, reducing the risk of atherosclerosis and cardiovascular disease.

q: When should I take statins?
a: It is best to consult your doctor about the specific time of day to take your statin medication.

q: What should I do if I forget to take my statin dose?
a: If you forget to take a dose of your statin medication, simply take your next dose as usual the following day. Do not take an extra dose to make up for the missed one.

q: Can statins interact with other medicines?
a: Yes, it is important to discuss any other medicines you are taking with your doctor, as statins can sometimes interact with other medications and increase the risk of serious side effects.

q: What are the common side effects of statins?
a: Many people who take statins experience no or very few side effects. However, some individuals may experience minor side effects such as diarrhea, headache, or nausea.

q: Are there alternatives to statins?
i: Lifestyle changes such as maintaining a healthy diet, regular exercise, maintaining a healthy weight, limiting alcohol consumption, and quitting smoking can be alternative options.
a: Before suggesting statins, doctors usually recommend lifestyle changes to reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease. Statins may be recommended if these measures do not help.

q: What are the types of statins available in the UK?
a: There are five types of statins available on prescription in the UK: atorvastatin (Lipitor), fluvastatin (Lescol), pravastatin (Lipostat), rosuvastatin (Crestor), and simvastatin (Zocor).
